Identifying Characteristics: Black, grey or brown, highly domed shells
Head is vaguely triangular in shape, with a pointed snout and sharp beak, and yellow-green striping from the tip of the nose to the neck
Also called the “stinkpot”—a common musk turtle may emit a foul smell from glands on the corners of the plastron that exude an orange liquid
Biology: Males become sexually mature at 4 years old and females at closer to 10 years
The female digs shallow nests at the water's edge under rotting logs or dead leaves
Females lay between one and nine eggs sometime between February and June
The hatchlings emerge 60 to 84 days later
Diet: Aquatic invertebrates including crayfish, freshwater clams, snails, aquatic larvae, tadpoles and various insects
Hatchling's diet is much more carnivorous than an adult's—can slowly acquire a taste for aquatic plants as the turtle matures
Habitat: Wetland habitats and littoral zones—particularly shallow watercourses with a slow current and muddy bottom
Permanent bodies of water—shallow streams, ponds, rivers, or clear water lakes
Hibernate buried in the mud under logs, or in muskrat lodges
Range: Eastern United States from southern Maine in the north, and south through to Florida
Also found west to central Texas, with a population located in central Wisconsin
